FacilityStr1: North Calumet Road & County Line Rd

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Storage tank(s), hoses, valves and personal protective equipment
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Only employees trained by the Oklahoma Department of Agriculture in the safe handling and dispensing of anhydrous ammonia are permitted to dispense to customers. The storage tank(s) & connections/transfer hoses, etc. are in compliance with OSHA's anhydrous ammonia standard 29 CFR 1910.111.  Only approved components appropriate for anhydrous ammonia are permitted to be installed during routine preventive maintenance of system components by trained employees or an authorized contractor.  Critical parts are replaced on a continuous basis to prevent failure.  System includes popoff valves to prevent overpressurization.

The storage tank(s) and system are inspected regularly by staff, insurance carrier, and the State of Oklahoma Department of Agriculture.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Shawnee Milling Company operates rural feed stores offering anhydrous ammonia to local farmers.  Onsite storage and dispensing of this toxic chemical varies in quantities based on seasonal application demand.  For approximately 3-4 months of the year, maximum quantities of anhydrous ammonia are reduced to less than 20% (48,600 pounds) of the maximum quantity of 257,040 pounds held in storage.

The company ensures that tanks and components are regularly maintained by trained employees and/or qualified contractors.  This facility is regularly inspected by employees, it's insurance carrier and the State of Oklahoma Department of Agriculture.  This facility could have as much as 257,040 pounds of anhydrous ammonia onsite at its peak sales period, as administrative operating procedures limit storage capacity of the tanks to 85%.

Storage tank(s) and system components are replaced on a regular basis by qualified staff or contractors.

The worst case scenario is structural damage to one of the two bulk storage tanks containing, at peak periods, up to 128,520 pounds of NH3.  Failure would result in a near-full release of ammonia within 10 minutes in a rural environment.  The toxic endpoint has been calculated to be 6.9 miles from the tank at which point it would be dispersed enough to no longer pose a hazard to the public.  Public receptors include residences.  There are no environmental receptors within the distance to the endpoint.

The more probable alternative accidental release would involve a ruptured disk or relief valve failure that could potentially result in up to 200 pounds of anhydrous ammonia being released before an emergency shutoff valve was activated.  The toxic endpoint would be limited to 0.3 miles whilch would expose very few residences and no other commercial, public or environmental receptors.

This facility has not had a reportable accidental release in the past five years.

This facility follows the emergency response plan established by the Canadian

County LEPC and coordinated with the Okarche Fire Department.  Employees are not permitted to respond to any accidental release that would require the donning of respirators.  Employees are instructed to notify emergency response authorities in the event of an accidental release and to evacuate the area as appropriate.
